case_vignette: A 20-year-old man is brought to the emergency department 20 minutes after he sustained a stab wound to his back during an altercation. He reports weakness and numbness of the lower extremities. He has no history of serious illness. On arrival, he is alert and cooperative. His pulse is 90/min, and blood pressure is 100/65 mm Hg. Examination shows a deep 4-cm laceration on his back next to the vertebral column at the level of the T10 vertebra. Neurologic examination shows right-sided flaccid paralysis with a diminished vibratory sense ipsilaterally, decreased sensation to light touch at the level of his laceration and below, and left-sided loss of hot, cold, and pin-prick sensation at the level of the umbilicus and below. Deep tendon reflexes of his right lower extremity are 4+ and symmetrical. Babinski sign is absent bilaterally. The remainder of the examination shows no abnormalities.
question: Which  is the most likely diagnosis?

multiturn_conversation.content: You are an AI doctor specializing in Neurology. Arrive at a diagnosis of a patient's medical condition. Ask simple 1 line questions, one question at a time. Continue asking questions until you're 100% confident of the diagnosis. The questions should cover age and sex of the patient, current symptoms, medical history of illness and medications, and relevant family history if necessary. Keep your questions short and brief to not confuse the patient.  After you're done asking questions, give the final diagnosis as a short response. Do not explain. You must state '**Final Diagnosis:**' at the beginning of your response, otherwise you will be penalized.
Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm feeling weakness and numbness in my legs.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I've been experiencing these symptoms for about 20 minutes.
Do you have any associated symptoms like chest pain, difficulty breathing, or changes in your vision or speech?
No, I don't have any of those symptoms.
Have you had any recent injuries, falls, or vaccinations?
Yes, I was stabbed in the back during a fight.
Are you experiencing any bleeding or did you receive medical attention for the stab wound?
I have a deep cut on my back and I'm currently at the emergency department for it.
Are you able to move your legs at all, or is the weakness preventing any movement?
I can't move my right leg at all.
Did the weakness in your legs come on suddenly after the injury?
Yes, it happened right after I got stabbed.
Given the circumstances, has a CT scan or MRI been performed to assess the extent of the injury?
I'm just a patient; I don't know what tests the doctors have planned for me yet.
Are you currently experiencing any loss of sensation or changes in bowel or bladder control?
I'm feeling decreased sensation to light touch on my back and below it.
Final Diagnosis: Acute spinal cord injury secondary to stab wound.

trial_0.summarized_conversation: A patient presents to the emergency department with weakness and numbness in their legs, which started about 20 minutes ago. The patient also reports decreased sensation to light touch on their back and below it.

Hi! What symptoms are you facing today?
I'm experiencing weakness and numbness in my legs.
How long have you been experiencing these symptoms?
I started feeling these symptoms about 20 minutes ago.
Do you have any weakness or numbness in your face or arms?
No, just in my lower extremities.
Have you had any recent injuries or trauma to your back or legs?
Yes, I was stabbed in the back during an altercation recently.
Do you have any difficulty with bladder or bowel control since the symptoms started?
The information about bladder or bowel control was not provided in the vignette.
Are you able to urinate and have bowel movements normally since the onset of leg symptoms?
The information about my ability to urinate and have bowel movements was not provided.

Final Diagnosis: Acute onset of leg weakness and numbness following a stab wound to the back likely suggests a spinal cord injury or nerve damage.
